CSS Test Page

A label

Example block-level help text goes in a paragraph with class "help-block".

This input is type="email" and required, so it's marked with an exclamation mark over there on the right. Once you enter a valid email, that exclamation mark will be replaced by a green check mark. This is how all HTML5 form validation features (required, patterns and types) are handled in Pocket.

This input has the class "invalid", you can use this for server-side validation.

You can also get the green checkmark by manually adding the class "valid" to an input.

Tables

Tables are tables. Give them the class `table-striped` to make them zebraesque. There's a small helper for showing the status of a row: any `tr` with class `status` plus any of the following classes will show one of those nice status indicators you see over there on the right.

  • Green dot: `on`, `yes` or `true`
  • Red dot: `off`, `no or `false`
  • Yellow dot: `warn`

Additionally, you can use `status` and its modifier classes in individual `spans` as well. For example:this works,this has a problem andthis one has probably had it.
